title: For Sale:  Insight M6 Handgun Laser
postcontent:
Insight M6 Handgun Laser /Tactical Illuminator.
The INSIGHT M6 Handgun Light w/ Laser (TLI-000-A1) is the most popular tactical illuminator/laser combination available today and is widely used for both law enforcement and personal defense because of its lightweight design and reputation for rugged reliability.
The M6's Xenon bulb delivers a peak output of 90+ lumens and is powered by two (2) 3V 123 lithium batteries (included) that give it a one (1) hour run time. The Class IIIa red laser is adjustable for windage and elevation and has a range of 200 meters.
The M6 Handgun Light/Laser mounts easily, without the aid of tools, utilizing Insight's patented Slide-Lock interface. Simply slide the unit onto the firearm's rail and lock into place with the spring-loaded latch bar. L-3 Insight Technology's Slide-Lock interface is designed to fit most pistols.
The M6 features a 4 position selector switch in conjunction with an ambidextrous rocker switch located on the removable backplate. The selector switch turns to Lock-Out, Laser Only, White Light Only or White Light and Laser combined. Once the desired output is selected the M6 is activated by using the rocker arm, toggling for either Momentary On or locking for Constant On. The rocker backplate on the M6 is interchangeable with any other backplate designed for either M6 or M3 models, and optional long gun and shotgun backplates with integrated remotes are available providing for greater versatility in illuminator application.
Like all L-3 Insight Technology products, the M6 is covered by a Limited Lifetime Warranty. 
Specifications:
Output: 90+Lumens 
Run Time: 60 Minutes
Visible Laser: Class IIIa Red/Range 200m
Interface: Slide-Lock Latch Bar Universal
Weight: 3.7 oz. with Batteries
Dimensions: 3.4" L x 1.6" W x 1.9" H
CODE: TLI-000-A1.
******** Makes your pistol, rifle, or shotgun a very effective "HOUSE GUN," lighting up the room when you hear those funny noises at night!

title: For Sale:  CRKT M1 Tactical Knife
postcontent:
This linerlock CRKT M1 Tactical knife was designed by Greg Lightfoot. It features a 3.125" modified tanto blade made of AUS-8 stainless steel. The blade has a non reflective black titanium nitride coating with Mako Flipper and dual thumb studs for ambidextrous one hand operation. Designer Greg Lightfoot describes the M1 as having "a refined Tanto shape with a custom-style hollow grind, slight belly and recurve with a hint of a drop point. The hexagonal textured black Zytel handles measure 4.5" closed. Features stainless steel liners and LAWKS system. A custom four position paddle clip is mounted at the pivot. Overall length of 7.625". Weight: 5.8 ounces.Teflon bearings at the blade pivot and an adjustable pivot screw allow for perfect blade action. Imported with a US patent Design. 
The LAWKS mechanism consists of a switch on the handle of the knife. When pulled back, the liner lock can easily be pushed back to close the knife. But when the safety switch is pushed forward, it acts as an extra lock ensuring the linerlock can not be used to close the knife, making the folding knife a virtual fixed-blade tool.
FEATURES:

Blade: Length: 3.125”
Handle length: 4.5”
Overall length: 7.65” 
Weight: 5.8 oz.
Zytel Handles

title: For Sale:  KaBar Becker BK-7
postcontent: This knife is awesome looking. It has a nice feel in the hand. Full tang. Comparing it to a KaBar this has the same combat capabilities with the added features of a survival knife. It would make a decent hacker of smaller limbs, and the tang extends beyond the grip for use as a hammer or window breaker. The sheath that came with it was pretty decent looking. I unstitched it and added a mixture of cardboard and duct tape to reinforce it a bit. I then sewed it back up. Not very professional looking but gets the job done. I have only used it about two times when I took it on hiking adventures in Red River Gorge. Still has a nice edge on it.

title: For Sale:  Ruger SR22 and Brick of 525 22lr Rounds (Remington Golden Bullets)
location: Pittsburgh and Surrounding Area, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania
postcontent:
Up for sale is a Ruger SR 22 with the stainless steel slide and a brand new unopened brick of Remington Golden Bullets 525 pack of 22lr rounds.

I bought the SR22 about a year ago and I absolutely love it, however recently got a good deal on a Walther P22 and it is a very similar gun.

After shooting both, the Ruger is a better firearm than the Walther in my opinion. I have put a brick of the exact bullets that I am including with this sale through the Ruger without one FTF or jam, something I cannot say about the Walther.  Also the Ruger has the smoothest racking slide I have ever felt on a handgun before.  However, out of my collection, the Ruger is the only duplicate in sense (with the Walther) and I want to use the money to buy 9mm subcompact (something I do not have).  Why is the Ruger being sold and not the Walther then? I just like the aesthetics of the Walther better, and I am using it to plink, so a few FTFs or jams here and there with bulk ammo with the Walther is not the end of the world.

Condition: The SR22 is in very good condition, as I meticulously cleaned it after every use, and I have taken to the range around 6 to 7 times, shooting about a brick out of it.  The are no cosmetic blems that I can find on the outside of the gun, other than a few small scratches that cannot be seen except very up close, but where the chamber meets the slide, there are some marks from burnt powder (normal from use).

The SR comes with everything that came with it from the factory: 2 mags, owners manual, Ruger lock, two different sized rubber grips, two different sized mag plates and so on (see the pic)

I am asking 275.00 cash for both (SR22 and Brick of 22lr).  I will only do a face to face transaction at a shop within the Pittsburgh Area or surrounding area, preferably Gunspricedright in Davosburg (they charge 25 for the transfer and have regular business hours, and are within 20 mins of the city). Buyer is responsible for the transfer fee.  Just send a message and I will get back to you promptly.  Thanks for your interest.

title: Want To Buy:  Want to Buy Used Small Good Condition - inexpensive working firearms.
postcontent:
I am looking for Good Condition - inexpensive working firearms.  Read below for what I consider Good, Fair, Poor Condition and Parts Guns.  It is very hard to purchase parts for most small guns especially those that went out of business.  Most generic pistols there is no way to get parts, a second firearm is necessary,.  Those listed below with names; many of the manufacturers are out of business. (Examples: Lorcin, Davis, Rohm, Jimenez Arms, and Jennings are only a few).  

Good Condition - The firearm works, it has all the parts, including magazines were appropriate.  The barrel inside (Bore) is bright and shinny, The firearm mechanics are tight.  The out side of the firearm does not have rust, deep scratching or the finish is 90% or better.

Fair Condition - The firearm works, it has all the parts, including magazines were appropriate.  The barrel inside (Bore) is shinny without rust or pitting, The firearm mechanics are strong to tight.  The out side of the firearm may have a small amount of  rust, some light scratching and / or the finish is 80% or better.

Poor Condition - The firearm has problems but it does work, it has all the parts, including magazines were appropriate.  The Firearm my have problems loading (jams). The barrel inside (Bore) is dull to shinny and may have light pitting, The firearm mechanics are weak but it does cycle.  The out side of the firearm may have some rust, light to deep scratching and / or the finish is below 75%.

Parts Guns - any  gun missing parts: safety, firing pin, springs, grips, sites.  (To replace these parts on a small gun will cost to much to make it worth any gun dealers time.  

Generic pistol prices / Pocket pistols

Pocket 22’s good condition - $20.00 Revolvers / Semi Auto
Pocket 25’s good condition - $20.00 Revolvers / Semi Auto
Derringers Any Caliber -$20.00

Parts Guns - $5.00 - $35.00 depending on the Make / Model / Size / and Need for the parts

Taurus, Ruger, Smith & Wesson and other name brand firearms will get a better price, depending on caliber, model, age and shape of Firearm.  Call or email for a price.

Beretta M1934 with two magazines. Shoots well and is in great shape for a 58 year old pistol. Will consider trades for .38 revolvers (Ruger, S&W) and semiautomatic pistols (Glock, Springfield, M&P, Walther). 

Description:
The Beretta Model 1934 is a compact, semi-automatic pistol which was issued as a standard service firearm to the Italian armed forces beginning in 1934. It is chambered for the 9 mm Corto, more commonly known as the .380 ACP.

Armi Beretta SpA of Gardone Val Trompia has a history in firearms manufacturing reaching back to 1526, when they were established as a maker of barrels. But it was not until 1915 that, responding to the needs of the military during World War I, they produced their first pistol, the model 1915. Beretta has become one of the world's largest pistol makers and the model 1934 (M1934) was their most numerous product in the pre-World War II era.

It was designed and purpose-built for the Italian armed forces. In the early 1930s, the Italian army was impressed by the Walther PP pistol. Beretta did not want to lose a big military contract to their German competitor and designed the M1934 for the Italian Army which accepted it in 1937. This model was followed by the M1935, which was similar to the M1934 in most respects, except that it fired a .32 ACP (7.65 mm Browning) cartridge.

Pistols made during the Fascist Era are marked with their year of manufacture in two forms: the conventional Julian date in Arabic numerals and the date in the Fascist Era in Roman numerals. The Fascist calendar commenced on 28 October 1922, so a pistol from 1937 may carry either "XV" or "XVI" as its Fascist year. Pistols taken by the armed forces usually exhibit acceptance marks stamped into the frame on the left just above the grip: "RE" (Regio Esercito) for the army, "RM" (Regia Marina) for the navy, or "RA" (Regia Aeronautica) for the Air Force, always in the form of an Eagle wearing a Royal Crown for the Royal air force. Police pistols may be marked "PS" (Pubblica Sicurezza). The Romanian military, at the time an Axis power, also purchased model 1934 (and 1935) pistols. The calibre marking appears as 9 mm Scurt (short in Romanian) rather than 9 mm Corto.[1] Romanian Army M1934's differ from Italian M1934's in that the Romanian pistols use the Russian sight picture, where the Italian pistols use the standard sight picture used by Western armies.

An M1934, serial number 606824, was used by Nathuram Godse in the 1948 assassination of Mahatma Gandhi. The pistol, manufactured in 1934, was carried by an officer during Italy's invasion of Abyssinia and subsequently taken by a British officer as a war trophy. It is not known how it came to India, but Godse was given the unlicensed firearm by a co-conspirator.

Design
Fitted with the characteristic Beretta open slide, the M1934 has a very reliable feeding and extraction cycle; the elongated slot in the top of the slide acts as the ejection port. It is made with relatively few parts and very simple to maintain. The M1934 is very robust in construction with a long service life if properly maintained.

9mm Corto (.380 ACP) is less powerful than most other military service pistol cartridges, such as 9mm Parabellum or .45 ACP. The magazine capacity is only 7 rounds. When the empty magazine is removed it no longer holds the slide back. The slide will come forward and close the gun unless it is held open by application of the safety, a separate operation, and this slows down the reloading of the pistol.

title: For Sale/Trade:  52" Welding Tank
postcontent:
Someone decided to abandon this tank where I work, and the building manager said I could take it. I know absolutely nothing about these things, but I did a little research, and here's what I can tell you:

Tank is a size "H," which is apparently the largest Consumer Owned Tank you can get filled. It's certified to be safe at 10% over it's maximum pressure, and is dated 2002, with a 10-year marking. In other words, it'll need to be inspected before it can be refilled, unless there's a re-certification mark that I missed. The tank had a helium balloon valve on it, and still had a little helium inside. I opened the valve and drained it completely. The tank does not have an owner's mark on the band, so I'm pretty confident that it qualifies as a C.O.C. Tank is marked "US GOVT," but had a nice, new-ish fill label on it, from Lande Gas. From what I could determine, the tank was most-likely sold off to the civilian sector, or else it would not have been able to be filled. That, or the government randomly throws massive balloon animal parties, then dumps pricey equipment behind the dumpster at a seedy strip mall, dozens of miles from any base.

Tank shows a little surface rust, but looks to be in very good shape, with no actual pitting. It is still mostly painted. I have no way to tell what kind of internal shape it's in, other than the fact that it still had a little gas in it, so one could *assume* that it holds air. I was also told that it runs $20.00-$25.00 to get the tank re-certified, and once that's done, it's good for another ten years.

Tank is about 112 pounds, and you'll need to pick it up in Conyers. I will need a Bill of Sale, which I'll type up. Basically, I just need you to sign off that you understand that I know nothing about the tank, can't certify that you're good to fill it up, and that you'll have it inspected before you try to use it. In other words, just normal liability stuff, because I really have no clue about anything related to welding, making animal balloons, piloting a Zeppelin, or whatever else these things're used for.

I'm asking $60.00, but I'm open to offers. I'd also trade for a drill press, ammo cans, or various other stuff that catches my eye. Come to think of it, I could use a wheel barrow, sledge hammer, and a splitting axe with wedges, too.

[EDIT: I'll add an image of the whole tank tomorrow...forgot to snap one today, and it's too dark out right now.]
